Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Hartmann’s Procedure and Intersphincteric Abdominoperineal Excision in Rectal Cancer

Trial_Design.evidence: eligible patients with adenocarcinoma of the rectum located ≥5 cm from the anal verge were randomised intraoperatively to HP or iAPE

Participants.evidence: eligible patients with adenocarcinoma of the rectum located ≥5 cm from the anal verge were randomised intraoperatively to HP or iAPE

Intervention.evidence: randomised intraoperatively to HP or iAPE

Objective.evidence: aimed to compare 30-day postoperative surgical complication rates between Hartmann’s procedure (HP) and intersphincteric abdominoperineal excision (iAPE)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was 30-day postoperative surgical complications

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was centralised and stratified by hospital, with allocation concealed until surgery

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of 194 eligible patients, 163 were randomised (80 to HP, 83 to iAPE)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The surgical complication rate was 39% for HP and 43% for iAPE (OR 0.83; 95% CI 0.44 to 1.54; P = 0.549)

Harms.evidence: Major surgical complications occurred in 14% of HP and 11% of iAPE patients (P = 0.573)
